packageMeta.name: purescript-foldable-traversable
packageMeta.description: Classes for foldable and traversable data structures

declarations.comments:
`Bifoldable` represents data structures with two type arguments which can be
folded.

A fold for such a structure requires two step functions, one for each type
argument. Type class instances should choose the appropriate step function based
on the type of the element encountered at each point of the fold.

Default implementations are provided by the following functions:

- `bifoldrDefault`
- `bifoldlDefault`
- `bifoldMapDefaultR`
- `bifoldMapDefaultL`

Note: some combinations of the default implementations are unsafe to
use together - causing a non-terminating mutually recursive cycle.
These combinations are documented per function.
declarations.title: Bifoldable

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `bifoldr` using `bifoldMap`.

Note: when defining a `Bifoldable` instance, this function is unsafe to
use in combination with `bifoldMapDefaultR`.
declarations.title: bifoldrDefault

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `bifoldl` using `bifoldMap`.

Note: when defining a `Bifoldable` instance, this function is unsafe to
use in combination with `bifoldMapDefaultL`.
declarations.title: bifoldlDefault

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `bifoldMap` using `bifoldr`.

Note: when defining a `Bifoldable` instance, this function is unsafe to
use in combination with `bifoldrDefault`.
declarations.title: bifoldMapDefaultR

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `bifoldMap` using `bifoldl`.

Note: when defining a `Bifoldable` instance, this function is unsafe to
use in combination with `bifoldlDefault`.
declarations.title: bifoldMapDefaultL

declarations.comments: Fold a data structure, accumulating values in a monoidal type.
declarations.title: bifold

declarations.comments:
Traverse a data structure, accumulating effects using an `Applicative` functor,
ignoring the final result.
declarations.title: bitraverse_

declarations.comments: A version of `bitraverse_` with the data structure as the first argument.
declarations.title: bifor_

declarations.comments:
Collapse a data structure, collecting effects using an `Applicative` functor,
ignoring the final result.
declarations.title: bisequence_

declarations.comments: Test whether a predicate holds at any position in a data structure.
declarations.title: biany

declarations.comments: Test whether a predicate holds at all positions in a data structure.
declarations.title: biall

declarations.comments:
`Bifoldable` represents data structures with two type arguments which can be
folded.

A fold for such a structure requires two step functions, one for each type
argument. Type class instances should choose the appropriate step function based
on the type of the element encountered at each point of the fold.

Default implementations are provided by the following functions:

- `bifoldrDefault`
- `bifoldlDefault`
- `bifoldMapDefaultR`
- `bifoldMapDefaultL`

Note: some combinations of the default implementations are unsafe to
use together - causing a non-terminating mutually recursive cycle.
These combinations are documented per function.
declarations.title: Bifoldable

Traverse a data structure, accumulating effects using an `Applicative` functor,
ignoring the final result.
declarations.title: bitraverse_

declarations.comments:
Collapse a data structure, collecting effects using an `Applicative` functor,
ignoring the final result.
declarations.title: bisequence_

declarations.comments: A version of `bitraverse_` with the data structure as the first argument.
declarations.title: bifor_

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `bifoldr` using `bifoldMap`.

Note: when defining a `Bifoldable` instance, this function is unsafe to
use in combination with `bifoldMapDefaultR`.
declarations.title: bifoldrDefault

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `bifoldl` using `bifoldMap`.

Note: when defining a `Bifoldable` instance, this function is unsafe to
use in combination with `bifoldMapDefaultL`.
declarations.title: bifoldlDefault

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `bifoldMap` using `bifoldr`.

Note: when defining a `Bifoldable` instance, this function is unsafe to
use in combination with `bifoldrDefault`.
declarations.title: bifoldMapDefaultR

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `bifoldMap` using `bifoldl`.

Note: when defining a `Bifoldable` instance, this function is unsafe to
use in combination with `bifoldlDefault`.

declarations.comments: Fold a data structure, accumulating values in a monoidal type.
declarations.title: bifold

declarations.comments: Test whether a predicate holds at any position in a data structure.
declarations.title: biany

declarations.comments: Test whether a predicate holds at all positions in a data structure.
declarations.title: biall

declarations.comments:
`Bitraversable` represents data structures with two type arguments which can be
traversed.

A traversal for such a structure requires two functions, one for each type
argument. Type class instances should choose the appropriate function based
on the type of the element encountered at each point of the traversal.

Default implementations are provided by the following functions:

- `bitraverseDefault`
- `bisequenceDefault`
declarations.title: Bitraversable

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `bitraverse` using `bisequence` and `bimap`.
declarations.title: bitraverseDefault

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `bisequence` using `bitraverse`.
declarations.title: bisequenceDefault

declarations.comments: Traverse a data structure, accumulating effects and results using an `Applicative` functor.
declarations.title: bifor

declarations.comments:
`Foldable` represents data structures which can be _folded_.

- `foldr` folds a structure from the right
- `foldl` folds a structure from the left
- `foldMap` folds a structure by accumulating values in a `Monoid`

Default implementations are provided by the following functions:

- `foldrDefault`
- `foldlDefault`
- `foldMapDefaultR`
- `foldMapDefaultL`

Note: some combinations of the default implementations are unsafe to
use together - causing a non-terminating mutually recursive cycle.
These combinations are documented per function.
declarations.title: Foldable

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `foldr` using `foldMap`.

Note: when defining a `Foldable` instance, this function is unsafe to use
in combination with `foldMapDefaultR`.
declarations.title: foldrDefault

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `foldl` using `foldMap`.

Note: when defining a `Foldable` instance, this function is unsafe to use
in combination with `foldMapDefaultL`.
declarations.title: foldlDefault

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `foldMap` using `foldl`.

Note: when defining a `Foldable` instance, this function is unsafe to use
in combination with `foldlDefault`.
declarations.title: foldMapDefaultL

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `foldMap` using `foldr`.

Note: when defining a `Foldable` instance, this function is unsafe to use
in combination with `foldrDefault`.
declarations.title: foldMapDefaultR

declarations.comments: Fold a data structure, accumulating values in some `Monoid`.
declarations.title: fold

declarations.comments:
Similar to 'foldl', but the result is encapsulated in a monad.

Note: this function is not generally stack-safe, e.g., for monads which
build up thunks a la `Eff`.
declarations.title: foldM

declarations.comments:
Traverse a data structure, performing some effects encoded by an
`Applicative` functor at each value, ignoring the final result.

For example:

```purescript
traverse_ print [1, 2, 3]
```
declarations.title: traverse_

declarations.comments:
A version of `traverse_` with its arguments flipped.

This can be useful when running an action written using do notation
for every element in a data structure:

For example:

```purescript
for_ [1, 2, 3] \n -> do
  print n
  trace "squared is"
  print (n * n)
```
declarations.title: for_

declarations.comments:
Perform all of the effects in some data structure in the order
given by the `Foldable` instance, ignoring the final result.

For example:

```purescript
sequence_ [ trace "Hello, ", trace " world!" ]
```
declarations.title: sequence_

declarations.comments: Combines a collection of elements using the `Alt` operation.
declarations.title: oneOf

declarations.comments: Folds a structure into some `Plus`.
declarations.title: oneOfMap

declarations.comments:
Fold a data structure, accumulating values in some `Monoid`,
combining adjacent elements using the specified separator.
declarations.title: intercalate

declarations.comments:
`foldMap` but with each element surrounded by some fixed value.

For example:

```purescript
> surroundMap "*" show []
= "*"

> surroundMap "*" show [1]
= "*1*"

> surroundMap "*" show [1, 2]
= "*1*2*"

> surroundMap "*" show [1, 2, 3]
= "*1*2*3*"
```
declarations.title: surroundMap

declarations.comments:
`fold` but with each element surrounded by some fixed value.

For example:

```purescript
> surround "*" []
= "*"

> surround "*" ["1"]
= "*1*"

> surround "*" ["1", "2"]
= "*1*2*"

> surround "*" ["1", "2", "3"]
= "*1*2*3*"
```
declarations.title: surround

declarations.comments:
The conjunction of all the values in a data structure. When specialized
to `Boolean`, this function will test whether all of the values in a data
structure are `true`.
declarations.title: and

declarations.comments:
The disjunction of all the values in a data structure. When specialized
to `Boolean`, this function will test whether any of the values in a data
structure is `true`.
declarations.title: or

declarations.comments:
`all f` is the same as `and <<< map f`; map a function over the structure,
and then get the conjunction of the results.
declarations.title: all

declarations.comments:
`any f` is the same as `or <<< map f`; map a function over the structure,
and then get the disjunction of the results.
declarations.title: any

declarations.comments: Find the sum of the numeric values in a data structure.
declarations.title: sum

declarations.comments: Find the product of the numeric values in a data structure.
declarations.title: product

declarations.comments: Test whether a value is an element of a data structure.
declarations.title: elem

declarations.comments: Test whether a value is not an element of a data structure.
declarations.title: notElem

declarations.comments: Try to get nth element from the left in a data structure
declarations.title: indexl

declarations.comments: Try to get nth element from the right in a data structure
declarations.title: indexr

declarations.comments: Try to find an element in a data structure which satisfies a predicate.
declarations.title: find

declarations.comments: Try to find an element in a data structure which satisfies a predicate mapping.
declarations.title: findMap

declarations.comments: Find the largest element of a structure, according to its `Ord` instance.
declarations.title: maximum

declarations.comments:
Find the largest element of a structure, according to a given comparison
function. The comparison function should represent a total ordering (see
the `Ord` type class laws); if it does not, the behaviour is undefined.
declarations.title: maximumBy

declarations.comments: Find the smallest element of a structure, according to its `Ord` instance.
declarations.title: minimum

declarations.comments:
Find the smallest element of a structure, according to a given comparison
function. The comparison function should represent a total ordering (see
the `Ord` type class laws); if it does not, the behaviour is undefined.
declarations.title: minimumBy

declarations.comments:
Test whether the structure is empty.
Optimized for structures that are similar to cons-lists, because there
is no general way to do better.
declarations.title: null

declarations.comments:
Returns the size/length of a finite structure.
Optimized for structures that are similar to cons-lists, because there
is no general way to do better.
declarations.title: length

declarations.comments:
A `Foldable` with an additional index.
A `FoldableWithIndex` instance must be compatible with its `Foldable`
instance
```purescript
foldr f = foldrWithIndex (const f)
foldl f = foldlWithIndex (const f)
foldMap f = foldMapWithIndex (const f)
```

Default implementations are provided by the following functions:

- `foldrWithIndexDefault`
- `foldlWithIndexDefault`
- `foldMapWithIndexDefaultR`
- `foldMapWithIndexDefaultL`

Note: some combinations of the default implementations are unsafe to
use together - causing a non-terminating mutually recursive cycle.
These combinations are documented per function.
declarations.title: FoldableWithIndex

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `foldrWithIndex` using `foldMapWithIndex`.

Note: when defining a `FoldableWithIndex` instance, this function is
unsafe to use in combination with `foldMapWithIndexDefaultR`.
declarations.title: foldrWithIndexDefault

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `foldlWithIndex` using `foldMapWithIndex`.

Note: when defining a `FoldableWithIndex` instance, this function is
unsafe to use in combination with `foldMapWithIndexDefaultL`.
declarations.title: foldlWithIndexDefault

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `foldMapWithIndex` using `foldrWithIndex`.

Note: when defining a `FoldableWithIndex` instance, this function is
unsafe to use in combination with `foldrWithIndexDefault`.
declarations.title: foldMapWithIndexDefaultR

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `foldMapWithIndex` using `foldlWithIndex`.

Note: when defining a `FoldableWithIndex` instance, this function is
unsafe to use in combination with `foldlWithIndexDefault`.
declarations.title: foldMapWithIndexDefaultL

declarations.comments:
Similar to 'foldlWithIndex', but the result is encapsulated in a monad.

Note: this function is not generally stack-safe, e.g., for monads which
build up thunks a la `Eff`.
declarations.title: foldWithIndexM

declarations.comments:
Traverse a data structure with access to the index, performing some
effects encoded by an `Applicative` functor at each value, ignoring the
final result.

For example:

```purescript
> traverseWithIndex_ (curry logShow) ["a", "b", "c"]
(Tuple 0 "a")
(Tuple 1 "b")
(Tuple 2 "c")
```
declarations.title: traverseWithIndex_

declarations.comments:
A version of `traverseWithIndex_` with its arguments flipped.

This can be useful when running an action written using do notation
for every element in a data structure:

For example:

```purescript
forWithIndex_ ["a", "b", "c"] \i x -> do
  logShow i
  log x
```
declarations.title: forWithIndex_

declarations.comments:
`foldMapWithIndex` but with each element surrounded by some fixed value.

For example:

```purescript
> surroundMapWithIndex "*" (\i x -> show i <> x) []
= "*"

> surroundMapWithIndex "*" (\i x -> show i <> x) ["a"]
= "*0a*"

> surroundMapWithIndex "*" (\i x -> show i <> x) ["a", "b"]
= "*0a*1b*"

> surroundMapWithIndex "*" (\i x -> show i <> x) ["a", "b", "c"]
= "*0a*1b*2c*"
```
declarations.title: surroundMapWithIndex

declarations.comments:
`allWithIndex f` is the same as `and <<< mapWithIndex f`; map a function over the
structure, and then get the conjunction of the results.
declarations.title: allWithIndex

declarations.comments:
`anyWithIndex f` is the same as `or <<< mapWithIndex f`; map a function over the
structure, and then get the disjunction of the results.
declarations.title: anyWithIndex

declarations.comments:
Try to find an element in a data structure which satisfies a predicate
with access to the index.
declarations.title: findWithIndex

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `foldr` using `foldrWithIndex`
declarations.title: foldrDefault

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `foldl` using `foldlWithIndex`
declarations.title: foldlDefault

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `foldMap` using `foldMapWithIndex`
declarations.title: foldMapDefault

declarations.comments:
A `Functor` with an additional index.
Instances must satisfy a modified form of the `Functor` laws
```purescript
mapWithIndex (\_ a -> a) = identity
mapWithIndex f . mapWithIndex g = mapWithIndex (\i -> f i <<< g i)
```
and be compatible with the `Functor` instance
```purescript
map f = mapWithIndex (const f)
```
declarations.title: FunctorWithIndex

declarations.comments: A default implementation of Functor's `map` in terms of `mapWithIndex`
declarations.title: mapDefault

declarations.comments:
`Foldable1` represents data structures with a minimum of one element that can be _folded_.

- `fold1` folds a structure using a `Semigroup` instance
- `foldMap1` folds a structure by accumulating values in a `Semigroup`

Default implementations are provided by the following functions:

- `fold1Default`
- `foldMap1Default`

Note: some combinations of the default implementations are unsafe to
use together - causing a non-terminating mutually recursive cycle.
These combinations are documented per function.
declarations.title: Foldable1

declarations.comments:
Traverse a data structure, performing some effects encoded by an
`Apply` instance at each value, ignoring the final result.
declarations.title: traverse1_
for1_

declarations.comments:
Perform all of the effects in some data structure in the order
given by the `Foldable1` instance, ignoring the final result.
declarations.title: sequence1_

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `foldMap1` using `fold1`.
declarations.title: foldMap1Default

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `fold1` using `foldMap1`.
declarations.title: fold1Default

declarations.comments:
Fold a data structure using a `Semigroup` instance,
combining adjacent elements using the specified separator.
declarations.title: intercalate

declarations.comments:
Fold a data structure, accumulating values in some `Semigroup`,
combining adjacent elements using the specified separator.
declarations.title: intercalateMap

declarations.comments:
`Traversable1` represents data structures with a minimum of one element that can be _traversed_,
accumulating results and effects in some `Applicative` functor.

- `traverse1` runs an action for every element in a data structure,
  and accumulates the results.
- `sequence1` runs the actions _contained_ in a data structure,
  and accumulates the results.

The `traverse1` and `sequence1` functions should be compatible in the
following sense:

- `traverse1 f xs = sequence1 (f <$> xs)`
- `sequence1 = traverse1 identity`

`Traversable1` instances should also be compatible with the corresponding
`Foldable1` instances, in the following sense:

- `foldMap1 f = runConst <<< traverse1 (Const <<< f)`

Default implementations are provided by the following functions:

- `traverse1Default`
- `sequence1Default`
declarations.title: Traversable1

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `traverse1` using `sequence1`.
declarations.title: traverse1Default

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `sequence1` using `traverse1`.
declarations.title: sequence1Default

declarations.comments:
`Foldable` represents data structures which can be _folded_.

- `foldr` folds a structure from the right
- `foldl` folds a structure from the left
- `foldMap` folds a structure by accumulating values in a `Monoid`

Default implementations are provided by the following functions:

- `foldrDefault`
- `foldlDefault`
- `foldMapDefaultR`
- `foldMapDefaultL`

Note: some combinations of the default implementations are unsafe to
use together - causing a non-terminating mutually recursive cycle.
These combinations are documented per function.
declarations.title: Foldable

declarations.comments:
Traverse a data structure, performing some effects encoded by an
`Applicative` functor at each value, ignoring the final result.

For example:

```purescript
traverse_ print [1, 2, 3]
```
declarations.title: traverse_

declarations.comments: Find the sum of the numeric values in a data structure.
declarations.title: sum

declarations.comments:
Perform all of the effects in some data structure in the order
given by the `Foldable` instance, ignoring the final result.

For example:

```purescript
sequence_ [ trace "Hello, ", trace " world!" ]
```
declarations.title: sequence_

declarations.comments: Find the product of the numeric values in a data structure.
declarations.title: product

declarations.comments:
The disjunction of all the values in a data structure. When specialized
to `Boolean`, this function will test whether any of the values in a data
structure is `true`.
declarations.title: or

declarations.comments: Combines a collection of elements using the `Alt` operation.
declarations.title: oneOf

declarations.comments: Test whether a value is not an element of a data structure.
declarations.title: notElem

declarations.comments:
Find the smallest element of a structure, according to a given comparison
function. The comparison function should represent a total ordering (see
the `Ord` type class laws); if it does not, the behaviour is undefined.
declarations.title: minimumBy

declarations.comments: Find the smallest element of a structure, according to its `Ord` instance.
declarations.title: minimum

declarations.comments:
Find the largest element of a structure, according to a given comparison
function. The comparison function should represent a total ordering (see
the `Ord` type class laws); if it does not, the behaviour is undefined.
declarations.title: maximumBy

declarations.comments: Find the largest element of a structure, according to its `Ord` instance.
declarations.title: maximum

declarations.comments:
Fold a data structure, accumulating values in some `Monoid`,
combining adjacent elements using the specified separator.
declarations.title: intercalate

declarations.comments:
A version of `traverse_` with its arguments flipped.

This can be useful when running an action written using do notation
for every element in a data structure:

For example:

```purescript
for_ [1, 2, 3] \n -> do
  print n
  trace "squared is"
  print (n * n)
```
declarations.title: for_

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `foldr` using `foldMap`.

Note: when defining a `Foldable` instance, this function is unsafe to use
in combination with `foldMapDefaultR`.
declarations.title: foldrDefault

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `foldl` using `foldMap`.

Note: when defining a `Foldable` instance, this function is unsafe to use
in combination with `foldMapDefaultL`.
declarations.title: foldlDefault

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `foldMap` using `foldr`.

Note: when defining a `Foldable` instance, this function is unsafe to use
in combination with `foldrDefault`.
declarations.title: foldMapDefaultR

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `foldMap` using `foldl`.

Note: when defining a `Foldable` instance, this function is unsafe to use
in combination with `foldlDefault`.
declarations.title: foldMapDefaultL

declarations.comments: Fold a data structure, accumulating values in some `Monoid`.
declarations.title: fold

declarations.comments: Try to find an element in a data structure which satisfies a predicate.
declarations.title: find

declarations.comments: Test whether a value is an element of a data structure.
declarations.title: elem

declarations.comments:
`any f` is the same as `or <<< map f`; map a function over the structure,
and then get the disjunction of the results.
declarations.title: any

declarations.comments:
The conjunction of all the values in a data structure. When specialized
to `Boolean`, this function will test whether all of the values in a data
structure are `true`.
declarations.title: and

declarations.comments:
`all f` is the same as `and <<< map f`; map a function over the structure,
and then get the conjunction of the results.
declarations.title: all

declarations.comments:
`Traversable` represents data structures which can be _traversed_,
accumulating results and effects in some `Applicative` functor.

- `traverse` runs an action for every element in a data structure,
  and accumulates the results.
- `sequence` runs the actions _contained_ in a data structure,
  and accumulates the results.

The `traverse` and `sequence` functions should be compatible in the
following sense:

- `traverse f xs = sequence (f <$> xs)`
- `sequence = traverse identity`

`Traversable` instances should also be compatible with the corresponding
`Foldable` instances, in the following sense:

- `foldMap f = runConst <<< traverse (Const <<< f)`

Default implementations are provided by the following functions:

- `traverseDefault`
- `sequenceDefault`
declarations.title: Traversable

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `traverse` using `sequence` and `map`.
declarations.title: traverseDefault

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `sequence` using `traverse`.
declarations.title: sequenceDefault

declarations.comments:
A version of `traverse` with its arguments flipped.


This can be useful when running an action written using do notation
for every element in a data structure:

For example:

```purescript
for [1, 2, 3] \n -> do
  print n
  return (n * n)
```
declarations.title: for

declarations.comments:
Fold a data structure from the left, keeping all intermediate results
instead of only the final result. Note that the initial value does not
appear in the result (unlike Haskell's `Prelude.scanl`).

```purescript
scanl (+) 0  [1,2,3] = [1,3,6]
scanl (-) 10 [1,2,3] = [9,7,4]
```
declarations.title: scanl

declarations.comments:
Fold a data structure from the right, keeping all intermediate results
instead of only the final result. Note that the initial value does not
appear in the result (unlike Haskell's `Prelude.scanr`).

```purescript
scanr (+) 0 [1,2,3] = [6,5,3]
scanr (flip (-)) 10 [1,2,3] = [4,5,7]
```
declarations.title: scanr

declarations.comments:
Fold a data structure from the left, keeping all intermediate results
instead of only the final result.

Unlike `scanl`, `mapAccumL` allows the type of accumulator to differ
from the element type of the final data structure.
declarations.title: mapAccumL

declarations.comments:
Fold a data structure from the right, keeping all intermediate results
instead of only the final result.

Unlike `scanr`, `mapAccumR` allows the type of accumulator to differ
from the element type of the final data structure.
declarations.title: mapAccumR

declarations.comments:
A `Traversable` with an additional index.  
A `TraversableWithIndex` instance must be compatible with its
`Traversable` instance
```purescript
traverse f = traverseWithIndex (const f)
```
with its `FoldableWithIndex` instance
```
foldMapWithIndex f = unwrap <<< traverseWithIndex (\i -> Const <<< f i)
```
and with its `FunctorWithIndex` instance
```
mapWithIndex f = unwrap <<< traverseWithIndex (\i -> Identity <<< f i)
```

A default implementation is provided by `traverseWithIndexDefault`.
declarations.title: TraversableWithIndex

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `traverseWithIndex` using `sequence` and `mapWithIndex`.
declarations.title: traverseWithIndexDefault

declarations.comments:
A version of `traverseWithIndex` with its arguments flipped.


This can be useful when running an action written using do notation
for every element in a data structure:

For example:

```purescript
for [1, 2, 3] \i x -> do
  logShow i
  pure (x * x)
```
declarations.title: forWithIndex

declarations.comments:
Fold a data structure from the left with access to the indices, keeping
all intermediate results instead of only the final result. Note that the
initial value does not appear in the result (unlike Haskell's
`Prelude.scanl`).

```purescript
scanlWithIndex (\i y x -> i + y + x) 0 [1, 2, 3] = [1, 4, 9]
```
declarations.title: scanlWithIndex

declarations.comments:
Fold a data structure from the left with access to the indices, keeping
all intermediate results instead of only the final result.

Unlike `scanlWithIndex`, `mapAccumLWithIndex` allows the type of accumulator to differ
from the element type of the final data structure.
declarations.title: mapAccumLWithIndex

declarations.comments:
Fold a data structure from the right with access to the indices, keeping
all intermediate results instead of only the final result. Note that the
initial value does not appear in the result (unlike Haskell's `Prelude.scanr`).

```purescript
scanrWithIndex (\i x y -> i + x + y) 0 [1, 2, 3] = [9, 8, 5]
```
declarations.title: scanrWithIndex

declarations.comments:
Fold a data structure from the right with access to the indices, keeping
all intermediate results instead of only the final result.

Unlike `scanrWithIndex`, `imapAccumRWithIndex` allows the type of accumulator to differ
from the element type of the final data structure.
declarations.title: mapAccumRWithIndex

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `traverse` in terms of `traverseWithIndex`
declarations.title: traverseDefault
